title: 113_hr4565
content: The "Startup Capital Modernization Act of 2014" increases small issues exemptive authority under the Securities Act of 1933 to $10,000,000 and includes preemption of state laws. The "Startup Capital Modernization Act of 2014" raises small issues exemptive authority to $10,000,000 under the Securities Act of 1933 and preempts state laws. An amendment clarifies State enforcement authority regarding registration requirements and does not limit other State enforcement actions under section 3(b)(1) of the Act. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 clarifies state jurisdiction over unlawful conduct by intermediaries, issuers, and custodians in transactions described under section 3(b). The amendment clarifies state jurisdiction over unlawful conduct in transactions described under section 3(b), excluding certain entities from shareholder cap. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions if the issuer meets specific requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission is required to issue a rule within 180 days to implement this amendment. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions. The exclusion applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of this Act. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions. This exclusion applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. EXEMPTED TRANSACTIONS. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to exempt transactions meeting specific requirements, including those where each purchaser is an accredited investor. Securities offered under Regulation A are excluded from certain provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Securities sold under subsection (a)(7) must be verified that each purchaser is an accredited investor. These securities are considered acquired in a non-public offering. The exemption does not apply if the seller is the issuer, its subsidiaries, parent, an underwriter receiving compensation from the issuer, or a dealer. The exemption under section 4(a)(7) of the Securities Act of 1933 allows for certain exempt offerings, with specific requirements for accredited investors. Transactions meeting these requirements are not considered distributions under section 2(a)(11).
